title: The Fight-or-Flight Response on Stage
description: One-minute skill: The Fight-or-Flight Response on Stage.

hook.text: Your hands shake, your mouth dries, your heart races. You're not dying â€” you're about to give a speech.

buildup.text: Your amygdala detected a threat (the audience) and flooded your body with adrenaline and cortisol.

discovery.text: Blood flows away from your brain to your muscles. That's why you forget your lines â€” literally.

twist.text: Harvard research found that reframing anxiety as excitement uses the same hormones more effectively.

climax.text: Saying 'I'm excited' before speaking measurably improves performance over saying 'I'm calm.'

punchline.text: Don't fight the adrenaline. Rename it.
